TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants are CARDINAL NORP nationals who live in GPE . Their further particulars are set out in the appendix . They were represented by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . The Government of GPE ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . The applicants were elected as members of ORG for a DATE period from DATE . The mayor prevented them from carrying out their functions and stopped paying remuneration to them for the period from DATE to DATE . The applicants and another individual sued the municipality for unpaid remuneration totalling the equivalent of MONEY ( ORG ) .
CARDINAL . As the municipality paid ORG CARDINAL to them , the claimants decided to withdraw their claim in respect of that sum on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG accepted in part the applicants’ claims for remuneration , to which they considered themselves entitled as members of the municipal council . The sums awarded to the applicants ranged between ORG CARDINAL and EUR CARDINAL , plus default interest amounting to PERCENT per year as from DATE in respect of CARDINAL of the sum awarded to each applicant , and PERCENT per year as from DATE in respect of the remainder . ORG discontinued the proceedings , at the PERSON request , in respect of the sum the municipality had already paid .

CARDINAL . Both parties appealed . CARDINAL applicant claimed an additional ORG CARDINAL and QUANTITY other applicants the equivalent of FAC each . The applicants also challenged the first - instance court ’s decision on costs .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG amended the first - instance judgment by dismissing the PERSON claims . It held that ORG had erred in interpreting the law . During the relevant period the applicants had not carried out their functions as members of the municipal council . They were not , therefore , entitled to remuneration for such activities , irrespective of why the situation had arisen . The judgment stated that the applicants were employed or retired . Their posts as municipal councillors related to public functions which could not be regarded as employment . Any remuneration would be due to the applicants only if they had carried out those functions . The decision to discontinue the proceedings in respect of the sum which the defendant had paid remained unaffected .

CARDINAL . ORG further amended the first - instance court ’s judgment by ordering the defendant to pay the applicants’ legal costs in respect of the ORG proceedings . It also ordered each of the claimants to pay the equivalent of approximately ORG CARDINAL in respect of costs advanced by the ORG . ORG judgment became final on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants lodged an appeal on points of law under LAW . They argued that ORG had committed errors of law in determining their claims .

CARDINAL . On DATE they also lodged a constitutional complaint . They alleged that ORG had breached their constitutional right to judicial protection . In their complaint the applicants mentioned that they had lodged an appeal on points of law .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the complaint . The decision stated that the applicants had at their disposal a remedy before the ordinary courts , namely an appeal on points of law under LAW . The court dealing with such an appeal had jurisdiction to review all the factual and legal aspects of the case . In those circumstances , it was not for ORG to hear the appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the ORG appeal on points of law as inadmissible . It established that the highest sums claimed by the individual applicants amounted to the equivalent of ORG CARDINAL . They were thus smaller than CARDINAL times the statutory minimum wage ( which , at the relevant time , was the equivalent of LAW ) . In such cases , an appeal on points of law was excluded pursuant to LAW . ORG decision was served on the applicants on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants lodged a second constitutional complaint , directed against ORG judgment of CARDINAL DATE . They alleged a breach of their right to a fair hearing in that ORG had committed errors of law . With reference to ORG decision , they argued that an appeal on points of law had been excluded in their case . The obstacle which resulted in ORG rejecting their first complaint had thus been overcome .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the second complaint as having been lodged outside the statutory time - limit of DATE . The decision stated that the applicants should have “ linked ” their constitutional complaint and the rationale of ORG decision to the decision of ORG even if , as it seemed to be the case , they had accepted the latter ’s conclusion . The decision was served on DATE .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL allows for an appeal on points of law against a judgment in which the appellate court has amended the first - instance court ’s judgment on its merits . However , LAW excludes an appeal on points of law in cases where the appellate court judgment concerns the payment of sums the amount of which does not exceed CARDINAL times the statutory minimum wage .
CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL ) , ORG is bound by a request from a claimant for proceedings to be started unless the LAW expressly provides otherwise .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that a complaint to ORG can be lodged within DATE from the date on which the decision in question has become final and binding , the date on which a measure has been notified , or the date on which notice of other interference has been given .
